bibdata.title: Prototype for endpoint to provide availability for mfhd
Run a full index for initial QA

comments.body:
The full reindex started t 2:46pm. I did not include the UPDATE_LOCATIONS=true flag because of https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/issues/1187. There are records with no holdings but the ones that have locations are indexed as expected. 
The holding locations have duplicate or triple strings because we updated the location to use the external_name. When https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/issues/1178 is done then we can proceed improving the location names https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/issues/1167.

comments.body:
I required_relative the path of the LocationMapsGeneratorService file but it would still not see it to initialize the class. 

I discussed this issue with @hackartisan. We thought it would be good to move the LocationMapsGeneratorService.generate in an ENV in the rake task.
@tpendragon supported the same solution or to add a rake task in this update_locations method. If we decide to keep it.

bibdata.title: Move the UPDATE_LOCATIONS in an ENV in the full reindex and the scsb …
Availability enhancements

comments.body:
@hackartisan I changed the code to return "Available" rather than "On-Site" and I broke some tests. 

Is there a reason to have both (sometimes Available and some other times On-Site) for the status text? If not, I can update the test to reflect the new status value. Otherwise we'll need to figure out when to return one or the other.

bibdata.title: Rename 'Rare Books and Special Collections' to 'Special Collections'
Add `temp_loc` to bibliographic/[:id]/availability.json endpoint

comments.body: @eliotjordan what's the value that goes in `temp_loc` ? true/false or an actual location?
orangelight is expecting an actual location.

Our temp locations are not currently included in our publishing profiles. This needs to be corrected before temp locations can be accessed. To fix this, we need to assign 'Current library subfield' and 'Current location subfield.' If those values are different than the locations in the 852 field, then they are temp values.

bibdata.title: Availability by mfhd

comments.body:
@carolyncole @kevinreiss do you have an example of what is displayed in the `enum_display` and `chron` fields? 

There are many `enum_*` and `chronology_*` fields in the ExLibris response and I am trying to figure how to combine them to mimic what you got from Voyager.

We will likely only use enumeration_a and chronology_i. That's all that was migrated from Voyager. In the future, we may end up using multiple levels of enumeration, which we would likely want to display in order (i.e., enumeration_a through enumeration_h, chronology_i through chronology_m).

Voyager only had one enum field and one chron field in the item record, Alma has the multiple layers.
@mzelesky great, thanks!

pul_library_drupal.title: Header appears to be underlined but there is not enough space between the text and the line

comments.body:
We decided on 3/31/2021 that we would add the "Website Feedback" button/form to PulfaLight. @sdellis will make the case to begin work on an implementation. We also decided that in order for the feature to fulfill its potential, the Library should use it to actively solicit such feedback from staff, faculty, and researchers. 

Before using this in production, we will need to decide who the feedback goes to, whose responsibility it is to mediate and respond to the feedback, and how we decide to prioritize or take action on resolving any issues that are relayed by our users. These are higher level questions and @faithc and @ccleeton will organize future meetings to address them.

pulfalight.title: Workflow to export finding aids to ArchiveGrid

comments.body:
:joy: Do we have to support this quickly? It looks like the way this worked was (deconstructing the logic):

Every repository has an RDF link (https://pulfa.princeton.edu/collections/eng.rdf), which points to every collection page. Presumably after that they'd harvest the XML EAD of those links (IE https://pulfa.princeton.edu/collections/MC124.xml)

We'd have to close #107 first, for sure, and then I guess re-implement that RDF link page.
Ahhh, yeah, I had zero clue how this was happening. Ha And I don't think it's urgent. #107 is definitely more pressing. :)
I think the workflow was entirely on their end (I didn't even know they were harvesting! Way cool!), with the exception of the content negotiation piece to provide the rdf, or am I missing something?

pulfalight.title: UV issues: not displaying MVWs, information/contents bars properly for some PCs

comments.body: @kelea99 I have not been able to reproduce this error in Edge or Opera using BrowserStack. IE 11 has its own issues, but we no longer support IE. I will follow up with Lynn and Cliff to see if we can debug using Zoom screen sharing.
This is a screen size issue. Lynn probably has a low resolution screen, forcing the UV into mobile mode.

@tpendragon Thank you. I can confirm this is an issue in mobile/responsive view. I bumped the relevant UV issue: https://github.com/UniversalViewer/universalviewer/issues/445

Based on the UV devs timeline, do we want to look at alternative approaches? Perhaps we can help them with a PR? Or use Mirador 3 for MVW until it's fixed in UV?

I think a short term fix would be to handle whatever Lynn's resolution is better - maybe put the table of contents above the viewer earlier, or shrink it for small screens?

Longer term a fix in UV would be great. Mirador 3 supports MVWs, but I find the navigation of them to be really confusing (especially after you've picked one). I know you prefer it, though, maybe something to user test?
I would be happy to help with setting up user testing, if needed, @sdellis and @tpendragon
Question: this is only finding aids. what are you doing to ensure visibility is aok for lower resolution (i.e. not defaulting to mobile/responsive view) in orangelight and figgy?
In Orangelight/Figgy there's nothing competing with horizontal screen space, like the table of contents is here. The same issue exists for actual mobile users.
Would it be possible to flag the condition and at least warn affected users that they are getting a reduced experience?

To clarify @tpendragon, I do not prefer the Mirador MVW experience, but just suggested it since it doesn't have this bug. I'm with you -- it's "clunky". We can look at fixing lower res screens immediately, but as you mentioned, it still doesn't help mobile users. Perhaps detecting and alerting users about the bug (as @cwulfman noted) would also be helpful until it's resolved as they will be completely missing a lot of content and may not even be aware of the bug.
